issues.summary: Program rules: Use Category Options in Expressions
issues.creator: Matthew Boddie
issues.description:
It would be extremely valuable to be able to pull selected Category Options in Program Rule Expressions.  Specific Category Options in our use case eliminate the need to ask specific questions, while underline the importance of others.  The ideal would be something similar to how the V{orgunit_code} functions.

Request also appears in the community from Oct 8:[https://community.dhis2.org/t/accessing-category-option-for-program-having-a-category-combination-in-program-rules/37177](https://community.dhis2.org/t/accessing-category-option-for-program-having-a-category-combination-in-program-rules/37177)

As an example:

In the our system, we collect entomological information.  For more robust analysis we use category options quite heavily; one program alone has 5 categories associated with it.  The categories are quite varied; 

1. Insecticide being used in the test, 
1. Species being tested, 
1. Wall being tested, 
1. Time Period in the campaign
1. Campaign specific Year of campaign

Distinctions within the category options lead us to wanting to be able to have program rules associated with them.  

Some Insecticides are ‚Äúlong-lasting‚Äù and would need to be tested over longer periods of times (i.e. more data elements), while other insecticides are not relevant at these longer periods and should not be answered.

Similarly, the kind of mosquito species that is tested will limit the options/presence of questions around the mosquito that is being used.

For now, and as further proof of the need for these values to control the experience of the form, we are actually collecting the same information in the category options again as data elements.  These data elements' main purpose is to allow for program rules to exist and be triggered so that the experience is as efficient as possible for the entrant.

Specific Example from VectorLink Collect:

!image-20221019-183155.png|width=947,height=284!

This is our WHO Tube program, with 4 categories.  The program goes through a WHO Tube Test procedure to look at efficacy of insecticides (with/without synergists, at varying concentrations) which are used to spray houses to kill malaria-transmitting mosquitoes.  The category options are able to give much more powerful analytics without need for multiplication of program indicators, resulting in a much cleaner/easier process to create and present resulting information.

There are many aspects to these category options that could be used to determine the relevance of data elements in the form.  The most obvious one is the Insecticide Tested Category; depending on the category option selected, the insecticide will or will not be a ‚Äúlong-lasting insecticide.‚Äù  If the insecticide is long-lasting, the measurements of test extend to 7 days.  If the insecticide is not a long-lasting insecticide, the testing will stop at 24 hours.

Because of the above, we currently have reproduced the category and category options into a data element with option set to allow for this show/hide of relevant DEs based on selection.   Below is a quick GIF of the program rule that show and hide data elements for one section (though, for this program, this hiding actually hides from other sections as well).

!WHO Tube Program.gif|width=942,height=965!

issues.summary: Program rules: Add additional source types to a program rule variable
issues.creator: Aleu Philip
issues.description:
Currently we have Source Types for Data elements for the Newest, previous and current event for a program stage.

There are however user requests and ideas for new source types:

** **Data element from the first/oldest event for a program stage:** Getting a hold of such a value is very critical in for example trying to compare with the current value to check progression of disease for example.
** [https://dhis2.atlassian.net/browse/DHIS2-9049](https://dhis2.atlassian.net/browse/DHIS2-9049): We are working on customizing for the program that tracking treatment for psychiatric patients. When a patient enrolled for a treatment program, we call it an episode. Each episode has follow up visits for treatment. There are some case patients doesn't come for follow up for long time or other words is lost to follow up. When patient return after a few month, we need to re-enroll the patient to the program again and restart the process and also want to see the history of patients. We consider this is the second episode. And there is a data element called Episode number. This episode number we would like to be generated automatically by using program rule. However, there isn't program rule variable defined to retreive value of a data element from the same program that patient enrolled previous time.¬†
- [https://dhis2.atlassian.net/browse/DHIS2-13388](https://dhis2.atlassian.net/browse/DHIS2-13388): We have a use case which two different user add event from different program stage. And one of them get value from event created by other user. We need to have a variable that can get value from a previous event of a program stage.

issues.summary: Program Rules: Enabling direct reference to DEs and Attributes without using variables
attachment: Rules with direct DE and Attributes.png
issues.creator: Rodolfo Melia
issues.description:
**Objective**: enhancing mass-editing by allowing [1] CSV prg rule import/ export & [2] direct use of DE and attributes on expressions (bypassing the need for prg rule variables)

This proposal is part of PSI's HNQIS project

**1. Direct use of DataElements and Attributes UIDs on prg rule expressions**
Currently it is mandatory to define a prg rule variable. A significant (majority?) of rules make use of the current event data value, making the process of writing rules convoluted, particularly if the rules are created outside the maintenance UI. The proposal is for attributes and current event data values to be directly used on the prg rule expressions.

issues.summary: Set expiry period for tracked entity attributes to revert to null
issues.creator: Chris Purdy
issues.description:
Often, it is important to collect sensitive, personally identifiable information about clients to be able to track them longitudinally and to be able to offer clients personalized care through the continuum.  However, once a client‚Äôs engagement with the health program has ended or lapsed for a significant period, it may be unnecessary to continue to keep this personally identifiable information on the client.  In these instances, rather than retain sensitive, personally identifiable information indefinitely, it is recommended to implement a mechanism in program configuration to specify tracked entity attributes for eventual expiry for replacement with a null value, and the period of expiry.

Proposed implementation:  In the ‚ÄòAttributes‚Äô section of the tracker program configuration wizard, a ‚ÄòTracked entity attribute inactivity expiry‚Äô field would be added below the tracked entity attribute selection window.  This field would have options to select a common period of expiry for select tracked entity attributes.

In the tracked entity attribute table below, an additional column with checkboxes would be added to select whether each tracked entity attribute would ‚Äòrevert to null after expiry period‚Äô.  This would allow the individual selection of tracked entity attributes for expiry, such as personally identifiable information such as name, address, and phone number, while leaving the option to preserve other, less personally identifiable attributes (on their own) important for analytics, such as date of birth and gender.

The expiry period would be assessed based on the last date when a new event was added to the enrollment or a change to the enrollment was made (whichever is more recent).  If this ‚Äòlast updated‚Äô date indicates a period of inactivity in the enrollment beyond the expiry period threshold, the values in the selected tracked entity attributes would be set to null.

An alternative implementation would use the period selector of expiry for each TEA for more granular control, rather than a global expiry period applied to each TEA with a checkbox selected.

issues.summary: Expression builder (Program rules/indicators): Display TEA/Data Element Value Types and Options
issues.creator: Chris Purdy
issues.description:
A current challenge for users building program rules is the need to be able to access option sets within the maintenance module to view the options, value types, and codes.  If the user does not know particular option set or value type assigned to a data element or tracked entity attribute, there is also the additional step of checking the data element or TEA for this information in the maintenance module.  This makes the process for creating program rules cumbersome.

Proposed implementation:
In the ‚ÄòEdit program rule expression‚Äô section of the program rule configuration wizard, in the right pane, program rule variables would be listed along with their associated value type in brackets eg. [TEXT], [DATE], or [NUMBER].  An arrow to the left of each program rule variable with an assigned option set would denote that it was capable of being expanded to show a list of options that could be selected and added to an expression.

In the ‚ÄôDefine program rule action‚Äô window, for certain actions such as ‚ÄôAssign value‚Äô, where an ‚ÄôExpression to evaluate and assign‚Äô is present, there would be a similar display for value types and options, where appropriate.  This would affect the following action types:
Assign value
Display key/value pair
Display text
Error on complete
Schedule message (limit variables displayed to only ‚ÄòDate‚Äô type variables)
Send message (limit variables displayed to only ‚ÄòDate‚Äô type variables)
Show error
Show warning
Warning on complete

issues.summary: Display TEA/Data Element Value Types and Options
issues.creator: Chris Purdy
issues.description:
A current challenge for basic analytics/M&E users for building program indicators is the need to be able to access option sets within the maintenance module to view the options, value types, and codes.  If the user does not know particular option set or value type assigned to a data element or tracked entity attribute, there is also the additional step of checking the data element or TEA for this information in the maintenance module.  This makes the process for creating program indicators cumbersome and in some cases prohibitive for analytics users that should have system access to create program indicators, but not access to configuration in the maintenance module.  This can restrict the creation of program indicators in the domain of system admins only, potentially creating a support bottleneck on what should be a basic analytics function.

Proposed implementation:
In both the ‚ÄòEdit expression‚Äô and ‚ÄòEdit filter‚Äô sections of the program indicator configuration wizard, in the right pane, data elements and attributes would be listed along with their associated value type in brackets eg. [TEXT], [DATE], or [NUMBER].  An arrow to the left of each data element or attribute with an assigned option set would denote that it was capable of being expanded to show a list of options that could be selected and added to an expression.

issues.summary: Options: Limit Top/Bottom X applied to totals
issues.creator: Former user
issues.description:
This feature is currently filtering the top/bottom X cells in the table. 

We would like to be able to apply it as well to the top/bottom X values in the total column (when present). 

**Usecases:**

For instance, top ten diseases in a hospital ward, but also have the details per month. 

While looking at causes of death for instance, it is more relevant to see the top 10 or 20 leading causes of death not every single cause in SMoL or ICD-10 that eventually make the pie chart hard to read. 
Having the possibility to limit the number of causes to the top 10, 20 or more will help focus on relevant information. Furthermore, there should be a possibility to have a system generated "other" category that will put together data for the remaining causes that are not in the leading causes.

issues.summary: Improvements for auto-generated tracked entity attributes and text patterns
issues.creator: Terence Scott
issues.description:
** Enrollment date: Request for the introduction of the enhancement enabling "ENROLLMENT*DATE(format)" to be included into the recognized TextPattern syntax relating to Tracked Entity Attributes. 
** Data element value: [https://dhis2.atlassian.net/browse/DHIS2-8993](https://dhis2.atlassian.net/browse/DHIS2-8993) 
** [https://dhis2.atlassian.net/browse/DHIS2-6600](https://dhis2.atlassian.net/browse/DHIS2-6600): *The issue is that auto-generating a unique sequential ID attribute--visible to the user at point of enrollment-- is simply not compatible with offline mode in Android. Currently, the device requests a fixed number of auto-generated sequential IDs (usually100) at every log-in. When the device logs out, these auto-generated IDs are discarded and cannot be re-used by another device. This means that the "sequential" ID will have gaps, so its not* ***really*** *sequential...*
*There are currently prefixes available to sequential IDs, such as org unit code. If we could create a sequence that is prefixed by username and, say, last 4-digits of the device ID, then the app could request a fixed number of IDs, work offline, and* ***never*** *discard unused IDs. But currently, the server is never reads the client's device ID, so I'm not sure its possible...*
** [https://dhis2.atlassian.net/browse/DHIS2-13990](https://dhis2.atlassian.net/browse/DHIS2-13990): *storedby:  the name of the user who requested the reservedvalue*
*device id:  the device type and serial number of the device where the reservedvalue was sent.*
** [https://dhis2.atlassian.net/browse/DHIS2-7450](https://dhis2.atlassian.net/browse/DHIS2-7450) *Current feature allows for generation of unique IDs by using sequence in text patterns i.e. using SEQUENTIAL(format). This produces a number (in sequence) for every TEI*
*The use case here is slightly different. Two TEAs are combined to give/produce (by concatenation) a unique ID. It is possible to have the same combination over time. However, when a concatenation would result in an existing value, we would like to have DHIS append a sequence number e.g. '001'.*
*The docs describe sequencing as* 
*"...so each possible version of the pattern will have it‚Äôs own sequential counter starting from 1....."*
*The request here is to have each possible* ***value** *(not version) have its own sequence._

In a number of applications, like for instance Malaria - IRS, we are using Tracker with a repeatable stage to capture the details for individual spray operators. In such and many other cases, there is no need to display the organisation unit in every event row - displaying it tends to take up valuable space and often expand the space required for each event row vertically, crowding out other widgets.

Having the possibility to limit the number of causes to the top 10, 20 or more will help focus on relevant information. Furthermore, there should be a possibility to have a system generated "other" category that will put together data for the remaining causes that are not in the leading causes.

issues.summary: All New Databases come with "Root" OU
issues.creator: Timothy Harding
issues.description:
A common question we get on the dhis2 users list is: "Why can't I enter data in data entry" or "Why can't I use events" or "why does analytics fail" and often it is their first instance, and they are missing the old 1,2,3

1. Create a Root OU
1. Assign a name to the first level in the heirarchy
1. Assign their user to that root OU

My suggestion or feature request is to do those three steps the first time an instance is booted to a blank database.

1. Create a Root OU and call it something like "HQ", "Global", "Root" or "Please Rename Me in the Maintenance App"
2. Assign the first level to the name of "Root"
3. Assign the Admin/District user's OU to that first one.

The only downside I can see to this is people spinning up a new instance and are expecting to load all the OUs from an external csv or xml or json. They would have the added step of matching the root OU's UID before they upload on the new box, or uploading it as a second root, and deleting the first.

As an alternative:

the first time admin/district logs in, you provide a first login page that accomplishes those above tasks:

** Please name your Root OU ************
** Please name this OU level ************
- and auto assign them

And have an option to skip this step.

issues.summary: Program rules: Assigning and validation for coordinates
issues.creator: Natalie Tibbels
issues.description:
**Assigning:**

It should be possible to assign data elements and attributes with a set of coordinates, using the normal ASSIGN action type in program rules.

Usecases:

** Assign coordinates from a Org Unit source field to a coordinates field
** Assign coordinates from a coordinates source field to another coordinates field
** Assign coordinates from V{XXX*orgunit*coordinates} to a coordinates field
** Assign hard coded coordinates to a coordinates field
** Assign coordinates concatenated from a string(using d2:concatenate) to a coordinates field (supported by the bullet point above)
** Assign coordinates from an option set or data element of type org unit - reference [https://dhis2.atlassian.net/browse/DHIS2-16515](https://dhis2.atlassian.net/browse/DHIS2-16515) 

**Validation:** 

We have multiple community based organizations capturing coordinates in the field using a different app and entering them later (manually) through event and tracker capture. Can we add a validation rule to keep the coordinates in a particular range (either min/max or within a boundary layer). They mix up longitude and latitude or enter totally incorrect numbers, leading to events appearing in the ocean. We would like data collectors to see at the time of data entry that their event is showing up outside of the country. Because the coordinates field is not a data element or attribute, can't create a validation rule the normal way.

issues.summary: Add toggle for Public/Private when saving new Visualization/Dashboard/Metadata

issues.description:
When performing a "Save As" operation, it would be helpful for those trusted with "Public Visualization", or "Public Dashboard" or "Public Map" have the ability to specify it as a Private entity.

For uses which have the "Public [entity]" authority, the app could display a "Public | Private" switch in the Save screen, which is by default "Public" (to retain current behavior) and will allow the user to easily make the AO private (without having to first save and then change sharing status).

This is to prevent these reports from publishing earlier than they are intended to be, and right now a user has to create a dummy favorite and quickly turn it private.

issues.summary: User access control down to single tracker case level
issues.creator: Calle Hedberg
issues.description:
Case-based Integrated Disease Surveillance Reporting (IDSR) require a much more fine-grained user access control design than what is currently available, where access to individual tracker cases can be provided to referral clinicians, specialists and/or emergency response personnel, as well as Case Investigators responsible for investigating the patient's home or work environment.

NOTE that managing such a high-granularity access control system will be time-consuming and/or resource intensive, so it is critical that we simultaneously look at designing functions that will ease this burden:
- the ability to have automatic tracker case access for certain individuals to all tracker cases fitting a certain profile based on attribute and/or data element values (typically disease specific, like when a malaria coordinator only get access to all malaria cases reporting within his/her area of responsibility)
- the ability to provide access on a time-limited basis, typically to be used for Case Investigators that have a specific time window for following up confirmed cases (or suspects/contacts). If a case investigation is to be completed within let us say 30 days, then the investigator's access to patient-identifiable details can be automatically revoked after e.g. 45 days unless the responsible disease coordinator over-rides it).

Another example of single user / single tracker access is the recently designed Integrated Community Service and Internship system for South Africa, where around 10,000 new graduates each year is able to apply for available posts all over the country for their one-year community service and/or their medical internship. In that case, each applicant needs access to all available data on available posts, accommodation, travel distances, and similar for the whole country - while they must ONLY have access to their own application (program instance) on the tracker side.
